review_title: USA Today ranked cdk 16th worst employer in the US for a reason.
main_text: I have been working at CDK Global full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The handful of people who are not inept are the only saving grace of this place.
cons: Very few people at this company have any clue what their job even entails. They basically laid off half the company in 2016 through 2018 for all the old employees making money (the ones who knew how things worked) and literally had NO operating procedures or training prepared so it basically became a complete free for all of ever competing opinions. Redoing work because of lack of procedures is so common you may waste an entire day doing what should have taken an hour if the expectations and directions were clear. Managers performance punish across the board. Ive only ever had to put in one HR complaint in my entire life and it was at cdk, i normally cant stand the 'kind of people' who file complaints but this was warranted. When I did I was written up for an "outburst" to my manager when I told her she was harboring a hostile work place by letting sales people lie to management about what internal employees had said and done (never been written up in 20 years of employment anywhere and am usually promoted at every job) this is of course a known problem but talking about it is strictly forbidden. The idea of an open door policy is a joke, HR eill dragtheir feet to protecttheir managers for weeks if you do speak up. After I promised to file a complaint with the ohio eeoc they took retribution via write up which requires staying in your department as punishment on me even though a vp of hr already said it would be a good idea to resolve my situation by us finding a new place for me, then the HR person eho allowedthat , who was friends with my boss, didnt even know "about those conversations" despite me tellingher aboutthem in email. Lol. Now I found a new job and put in my two weeks and despite assurance by HR that my funds would still be direct deposited theyve neglected to pay me...this is the MOST disorganized company in the world. Almost everone I know who worked here has payroll issues when they leave. And thats not hyperbole, I mean almost EVERYBODY. This place is allegedly a technology company yet cant sustain their internal systems which break down daily, often because they accidently fired a developer and.didnthavethe technical specs recorded anywhere, causing delays that are then the workers fault because the management, an ever rotating cast of VPs changing responsibilities who all are horrible at their jobs, wont prioritize fixing anything in lieu of some "new systems" that are always promised but never delivered. Theres a reason this place was the 16th worst place to work accorsing to USA Today in 2017. Trust me...run.

main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than a year

Eventually, someone thought it funny to place a jar on top of one of the cubicles and have everyone put money in the jar each time they wanted to commit suicide. You would regularly hear the drop of a coin in the jar and the office would erupt in laughter. MIND YOU, this is happening right next to the managers who laughed along too. And if you think that alone is bad enough, they eventually took the money and had a pizza party. Absolutely disgraceful. When if comes to promotions, I knew people who had been with CDK for many years and were only a Web Design Specialist 1. But the people who were in good with management would get raises before their 1 year anniversary. Also, as a contractor they will tell you they are going to hire you full time, but I was one of the last contractors to actually have that happen. They just string along contractors with false hope BECAUSE THEY KNOW THEY HAVE CHEAPER LABOR IN INDIA. And then there is the bed bugs. Holy moly. The other reviews are true. Bed bugs were found (again and again) so they fumigated the office overnight. Many of us asked to work from home that day because we didn't feel comfortable sitting in an enclosed office space with no open windows. Needless to say, we didn't get to go home. And last but not least......CDK HR is HORRENDOUS . This is going to make me loose my anonymity, but who cares. I suffered a back injury while working at CDK. QA is production, they basically just have the Devs roll out whatever they've made with minimal testing (if any) so defects are in the thousands and they take years to get fixed (if ever). Company seems to think that just forcing more work on the few left and tagging the emails with "Be Positive" is a good solution. I waited for 2 years for this place to get its act together because they kept saying "just be patient, things will improve". I think 2 years is patient enough. And things are just getting worse by the day. If all you need is decent pay and benefits and you're desperate for that, go for it. review_title: This is a Fictional Company, it has to be.
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Growing shorter by the day. There was a time when this company was actually focused on providing customers and clients with a good experience. You were given quite a bit of freedom in how you accomplished tasks, and were rewarded well for the time spent. Both offices used to be teeming with helpful, supportive coworkers who always had time to help. Used to. Were. Was. Not anymore.
cons: Let's get this one out of the way. It is morally reprehensible to attempt posting so many fake positive reviews on Glassdoor. You should be ashamed of yourselves. Any person could take a few seconds to invalidate any of these reviews. It's sad that you can no longer find any employees willing to write a legitimate positive review for this company. Let's start with your shady business practices. You are well within your right to hire contractors as much and for as long as you like. However, don't you dare make consistent promises to hire these people full time, and then string them along with some non-existent carrot. We all know the reasons. You opened up the office in Hyderabad, India, because you can realistically pay 3 of them for the price of one of us (if you even remotely paid us well, to begin with. It's why our job title is Web Design Specialist, and not Web Designer, so you can do that.) This practice is not new, nor is it uncommon. I know the people in our Indian office. They're hard workers. Good people. What's wrong is the way you are deceiving clients and customers. The folks in India are being asked to work in an industry that is vastly different than in their country, following instructions that can baffle even native English speakers. You have expressly forbade this team with communicating with clients, and instead have the team Stateside essentially play cleanup fixing (understandable) typos and communicating with clients, taking up time we could be using to help our customers. Back on the topic of contractor treatment, there have been innumerable instances where an employee could rightfully sue CDK Global for their actions (and in at least one case, this did happen, and CDK lost). A manager intercepted an HR complaint filed against one of her "favorite" employees for making a racist comment. Needless to say, the victim was a contractor, and they definitely found a reason to fire her. In another case, a contractor with chronic migraines had to take regular days off (contractors do not get PTO, they simply do not get paid). After providing medical evidence and a legal doctor's note about their condition, they were let go less than a week later for being "away from their desk too often". We also had a disabled employee in a motorized wheelchair, whom would have to wait outside the office floor every day because the company failed to provide a working handicap-accessible door. Then there are the health and safety violations. Bed bug infestations (yes, plural) have happened, and rather than closing the office to allow employees to work remotely, the building was sprayed overnight and everyone was made to come in the next day. An electrical fire broke out from one of the microwaves, and rather than evacuate, everyone was asked to continue working. The fumes for the rest of the day were so bad, that surgical masks were passed out to employees (not by management of course, but a fellow coworker). This brings me to our technology. We live in a constant state of building the metaphorical airplane in the air. Our proprietary platform is still missing promised features from it's launch over two years ago. It is missing features that were common in the platform's previous iteration. We are completely unable to respond to requests that our competitor's handle with ease, and are expressly forbidden from doing any sort of custom work to suit a customer's needs, no matter how small or large. Explicitly, this means no usage of HTML or CSS whatsoever. From a web designer. For a website company. In 2018. At the base level, we have no recovery tools. If content is deleted from a customer's website, or if published changes need to be undone, it is simply not possible. The customer's data and content is so vulnerable, how could you possibly trust us to take care of it? Things that are gone are gone forever, and that is just reprehensible. We do not even have a reliable way to center text on a web page. Think about that for a moment. If we are unable to perform such a basic task, how can we possibly be a leading tech company? You are a mockery. A farce. It's at this point, I must remind you that I am not speaking about a fictional company. This company is real. This company is doing all of these things and is getting worse by the day. This is CDK Global, and they truly deserve the reputation that they have gained.

review_title: The things that happened at this office would make a great TV Show, but a terrible real life experience
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than a year
pros: - There were some really amazing people in my department, but a lot of them are gone now - I genuinely love working downtown - Once you’ve handled this, you can handle anything
cons: Every rose has its thorns, but in CDK’s case, it’s more like an iceberg with a fun little flag on the tip, and below is the rest of the iceberg wrapped in barbed wire, electrified, with the Titanic dragged under the water and stuck there as tortured souls scream at you to get out while you still can. I’m sorry I didn’t listen, Leo. Let me take you on a journey. When I started at CDK, it all seemed really cool. The location is great, and we’re on the 28th and 29th floors, which makes for great snapchats. The people also seemed really nice, and there were people I got along with right away and are still my friends, even though they’ve moved to better things. It was even fun the first couple of weeks in training, because I had the freedom to be creative while learning the very specific in-house platform that we use. Things started to fall apart when I really got out of training and into the actual work. The way the amount of work done is measured is incredibly skewed. You can work on a case where you create 16 graphics for a dealer’s website and spend the time to make them look really nice and get the same amount of credit as someone who checked a box on a website. Since there’s no way to get credit for actual good work that you put a lot of time into, and you can actually get punished for not doing enough cases, most people here just pick out the easy cases or put in the bare minimum effort to get it done. This is not a comment on the work ethic of my team, but rather management’s incompetence and inability to recognize or incentivize quality work. A lot of people here were hired in on contract (why treat people well and give them benefits when you can get a no obligation test drive, amirite?) with the promise that there was a “high likelihood of converting to permanent full time CDK positions”, but that’s a lie. The real way to get hired on was to go to lunch with and make breakfast for the manager that had the most pull with upper management. You could also get it by telling this manager very personal details about your life and making her feel bad for you, but if you refused to reveal your life story, you were blacklisted. You may think this is an exaggeration, but I assure you, it’s 100% true. This kind of blatant nepotism has caused terrible employees who have no idea what good design is, no idea how our platform actually works, and who regularly fall asleep at their desks to move up in the company. The worst part is, upper management watched this happen and, while they always said they would try to make things better, did nothing to actually address these issues. Speaking of management, none of the managers know what our department actually does. The managers we have come from different places within the company, which would have been a good idea if there were at least one manager for the content team that actually had experience working on the content team. Instead, we’re forced constantly forced to explain why our problems are actual problems and why we can’t make 16 good slides and upload them all to a dealer’s website in 30 minutes, which is then communicated to upper management, like some inefficient, dystopian game of telephone. Upper management then either completely forgets what they’re told or doesn’t care, and gets upset at middle management when not enough cases are done, making middle management put more pressure on us. If there were just one (1) person on any management team who knew what a PSD is, I think this problem could have been avoided. On top of not getting credit for good work and management not knowing what we do, our team in India often produces poor quality work, if they can even interpret the request. This isn’t entirely their fault, since other departments or dealers often send in cases with instructions that are unclear, don’t provide all the information, or are just completely illegible. TCS gets trash, produces trash, and then we are obligated to fix it. This constant stream of mistakes and drop in quality has made dealers, GM, and CDK employees absolutely livid, and I honestly can’t imagine anyone in upper management truly believing TCS would be a good thing for the company when they cannot reach out for more information, and when there is no expectation for other departments to do quality work. While I’m on the subject of other departments, let me take a moment to tell you about that whole mess. When I signed on for this role, my job was to grab a case, reach out to the Account Advocate if any clarification was needed, and close it. Over the past year, I feel as though many of the duties of other departments have been pushed onto us. For example, Advocates have asked myself and multiple team members to reach out to the dealers for information. This is not our job, and we shouldn’t be expected to do the jobs of other departments. Still, we are often told to do things like this anyway because it provides a “good customer experience”. That would be all fine and dandy if TCS weren’t consistently providing a terrible customer experience and suffers (seemingly) no consequences. Now that I am about 900 words into this review, you may think I’m done, but no! Let me take some time to tell you about the door. There’s a disabled employee in the office, and since CDK couldn’t find a way to weasel out of ADA compliancy, they had to put a button on one of the office doors so it would open. They delivered on the button after a couple months, but that door still doesn’t work properly. It will almost never open on the first try, and sometimes won’t even open at all. It broke constantly for months, and apparently no one could figure out why. How many CDK employees does it take to fix a door? We still don’t know. I think I’ve now gone over every terrible thing everyone else has covered, but there’s something I haven’t seen on here yet; the microwave incident. A couple months back, we noticed there was smoke coming from the kitchen, and we soon realized that the microwave was literally on fire. Instead of evacuating everyone like a normal, ethical company would do, we had to take it upon ourselves to get out of the building. When we came back in, we were told everything was fine and to continue work as usual. We could have worked from home to minimize the possibility of inhaling dangerous fumes, or taken a half day, but no. I don’t even recall it being actually addressed by management. This isn’t the only time employee safety was blatantly ignored, but it’s one that hasn’t been mentioned. Overall, this company only cares about cutting costs, at any cost to employee well being or basic human decency. This place was spiraling towards the ground when I started, and now it has hit the ground and began drilling into the earth. I would honestly pay to see the day they hit that molten core and burst into flames, because it’s coming soon.

pros: Working there gives you A TON of experience because they make you do the job 20 people every single day. I’ve acquired so many skills as a result and the experience I gained there has made me extremely marketable to other companies.

It’s a heaping dumpster fire of a company, and it’s circling the drain, so don’t bother. Looks like they’re about to sell it/gut it, so don’t waste your time. If you’re currently there, just keep looking for other jobs. Don’t get upset or hung up on trying to fix things. Chances are, you’re not doing anything wrong. It’s just a failed company, that’s all. Just take care of yourself and quietly get out of there as soon as you can. Since everything else has already been said, here’s a fun story about how CDK can’t even keep it together in some of the most basic possible ways: One time, The facilities management company of the building sent out an email to all companies in the building saying that there had been a break in the water main- told not to drink the water or use the bathrooms, and the management company suggested that everyone evacuate the building. Shortly after the email was sent out, the manager of our department left for the day. Refused to answer any phone calls or any emails… just peaced out of there without a single word, not even halfway through the day. We tried to find anyone else who could give us an update on what to do. Finally, one of our department managers crummy little minions messaged our department saying ‘everything is fine now. There are water bottles available, and it’s safe to use the bathrooms again, and that we were not to leave’. Shortly after, the building management company sent an update to everyone saying that the water was still unsafe to consume, and do not use the bathrooms or flush the toilets, and it was highly encouraged that companies evacuate the building. We tried to contact the manager’s minion again, but, surprise surprise, they had left for the day. We contacted a manager from a different department who told us everything was fine. When we questioned them about the email we had just received, encouraging evacuation, they never responded. Finally, with no other options left, we reached out to a manager in a different state, who informed us everything is fine. Shortly after that, the building management sent out another update stating that the water was still unsafe, bathrooms could not be used, and that they were expecting the bathrooms to work tomorrow, but the drinking water would be unsafe for at least another day or two. We contacted the Out of state manager again, who appeared to be away from their desk for the rest of the day. Who knows. Maybe they were enjoying the luxuries of being able to take a crap at their office. Oh, and the office had bed bugs a few times. That’s the extent of how absolutely pathetic this dumpster fire of a company is. Some of the most basic functions of EXISTING are completely lost on them. It’s a miracle they’re capable of putting clothes on every morning. I feel bad for the dealers who have to deal with this smoldering tire fire of a business. I could go on for days about how breathtakingly awful and profoundly stupid this company is, but lots of folks have already covered most of it. But my point here is that they can’t even handle extremely basic functions such as ‘running water and restrooms for employees’, at one point, so the bar is unbelievably low.

review_title: Do you love bed bugs, low pay, and being disrespected on a daily basis? Boy, sign on up at CDK!
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than a year
pros: I honestly can't think of a single positive thing. Oh, I've learned how to deal with insane amounts of stress and anxiety. I've also learned how to discreetly take interviews in conference rooms. Oh, and Detroit is pretty cool. The office location was one nice perk.
cons: Where do I even begin? I'm just going to list out everything that happened or was an issue: -Promotions and projects are based on whether or not you're actively kissing management's tushy. You could be the most incompetent graphic designer whom clients regularly complain about, but if you make your manager breakfast/ refer to them as your mother (this is not an exaggeration,) you will be rewarded with promotions and projects. Hard work and skills means literally nothing, and loyalty will save you when you tell everyone to use the wrong branding colors for well over a year. -The most unethical hiring practices I've ever heard of. If you told me that CDK had some sort of backdoor deal with contracting companies, I'd believe you. People would REGULARLY have their contracts extended well past when they were initially told they would be considered for full time positions (and then would not be notified of the change to their contracts.) I've witnessed management lie to potential employees that there is a chance they will be hired on after the initial contracting period. That will not happen. Do not fall for it. -Management refusing to give employees their employment contracts. -Extremely low pay, and extremely varied. People in the same department, in the same position, with the same background and experience were paid $15 to $22. -People who were lucky enough to be hired on were often offered substantially lower pay than they made as a contractor, and were told the rates were non-negotiable. -Bed bugs. Several times. It probably happened because CDK pays so little that employees have to find housing in less than desirable situations. Management kept quiet on several reportings of bed bugs over a period of a few weeks. When the office was finally sprayed, employees were ordered to come in (even though most are perfectly capable of working from home) less than 12 hours from when the poison was sprayed (and is apparently still toxic if inhaled before then.) There were several pregnant women who were forced to come in. Zero humanity displayed from management. -Oh, every single job is being outsourced to India. If a problem was bought up to management (like Indian team members turning in extremely subpar work that was making clients incredibly angry) we were told "please support your Indian team members." -Employees were instructed by management to make it appear as if work done by the Indian team was actually done by US team members. Yet another extremely unethical business choice. -Your schedule could be changed on a whim, and if you didn't like it, oh well. -Benefits increasingly got worse and worse. The health insurance was extremely laughable. -95% of employees that left had to argue with HR to receive the full amount on their paychecks. I know of at least two instances where CDK argued that former employees actually owed them money. -We couldn't use the water in the building several times (e.g. no drinking water, couldn't use the bathroom, building management tried to force us to leave, etc..) -Our parking expenses were just straight up not covered. -The micromanagement from middle management. We're talking "why didn't you do 11 cases instead of 10?" each and every day. -The training provided was a complete joke. It would take months to train someone, and then they would be cut because management didn't like them as a person. Often, employees would start without laptops, or permissions to basic programs. It could take up to a week to get permissions. There was no training material in the content department for several years, as it was provided strictly orally. -Rampant racism can be found if you know where to look. -The clear psychological erosion from middle management. They will tell you literally whatever they think you want to hear, and then ban you from any promotions or projects because you bought up a business issue. -The issues within management. There are actually fantastic people just trying to earn a paycheck. However, they aren't invited out to dinners with their management, invited to exclusive birthday parties with other management, and they're disrespected on a daily basis for treating their teams like people. CDK management is like high school times one million. It absolutely could be a reality show if it wouldn't be extremely soul crushing to watch. -The content department was the lowest rung on the totem pole. Ineffective, unprofessional, and consistent problem employees from other departments would regularly belittle, mock, and go out of their way to make life difficult for the content team by sending in sub-par requests that were impossible to complete. Instead of reaching across the aisle and using these issues as teaching moment, management would ream you out and consistently take the side of other departments. -Zero opportunities for professional development, and zero transferrable skills. -The technology was extremely outdated, clunky, and down quite a bit. If I were a client, I would be absolutely livid. -I would say conservatively 40% of the current management has left from all departments. Even the fleas are jumping off this drowning pig.

This is a well understood strategy and (in and of itself) not a cause for concern. The problem was the implementation. Big Mac and the executive leadership team did not follow a well rationed plan: sell of lower-margin products, consolidate product lines, seek efficiency in product delivery, etc... review_title: Couldn’t get out of here fast enough
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I mean we got free bagels once a week which is cool, I guess? Other than that, none.
cons: I worked at CDK for a little over three years. It was never an amazing place to work, but it was alright in the beginning. It all went downhill from there. I’m 100% not surprised it was recently ranked as one of the worst companies to work for. First of all, the people. In my department at least, I felt like I was going to high school every day. So much gossiping, rumor spreading, and talking negatively about other people behind their backs. It was hard to connect with people because I didn’t know who to trust and I didn’t want to be involved in that. The workplace felt toxic. CDK does (or did) have a few great people, but oddly it seems that they all end up getting laid off eventually. I used to have an awesome manager at CDK, but his manager ended up taking over for my team, and I have never worked for someone so condescending and passive aggressive. I would be in phone meetings with her at home, with my phone on speakerphone, and my roommate was in disbelief at how she was speaking towards me and our team. I honestly don’t know how she is still employed there. Oh wait, it’s CDK, and they’re ranked one of the worst companies. Makes sense, actually. We were also forced to work 14 hour work days (at work until midnight) and were expected to be in a “war room” all day. No time set for breaks. That’s illegal, but again, terrible company and manager so I’m not surprised. Next, the work itself. Don’t even get me started on this. Let’s go with a metaphor. CDK is basically a junkyard car built with a bunch of random parts that shouldn’t go together and there’s no way it should work, but somehow it manages to just squeak by. However, it literally breaks down every day and if one part breaks, you quickly and lazily replace it with a similar part that *might* fix the car, but it won’t be as efficient as actually putting in the time, effort, and research to properly fix it so that it runs smoothly and effortlessly. Oh, and let’s say this car is being entered into a race. You tell EVERYONE (and I mean everyone) that your car is going to be the best and win the race. You also tell them that they should place their bets on it before you even see if it actually drives. You ignore everyone who suggests this might not be the best idea and you also ignore any suggestions for improvement. And then for some reason, you wonder why your car broke down in the middle of the race. Crazy, right? That’s CDK’s normal. CDK is very reactive, instead of proactive. They prefer to wait until something goes wrong before they fix something. I can’t even count how many times I asked for necessary and important improvements to be made to tools/processes and was completely ignored. Then when something went wrong that the improvement I asked for would have prevented, it becomes a huge issue and people finally start listening. Speaking of listening to their employees. I also did not get a chance to fill out an exit survey. I put in my two weeks and four days later was told they were going to let me go early. I emailed HR and asked if there was any way I could have my exit survey sent to my personal email address (they were planning on sending it to my CDK email). They told me they don’t send them to personal emails and essentially because I wouldn’t have access to my CDK email to fill it out when it came through, I was out of luck. Part of me thinks I was let go early BECAUSE management didn’t want me to fill out the exit survey. My last complaint - CDK doesn’t give a lot of their employees the position title they should have, and I think that’s because they don’t want to pay them as much as a position with that title normally would have. A lot of their employees should be making a lot more money than they do.

main_text: I have been working at CDK Global for more than 10 years
pros: The front line management at CDK seems to care about employees. The employees who remain after several layoffs are good, smart people.
cons: The focus of upper management is to plump up the bottom line, thus making it attractive to private equity firms. This is not a rumor. You can find articles posted on the internet last January about a failed sale attempt. CDK's customers and employees are bearing the brunt of of this focus. CDK has made a concerted effort to move jobs from the US to India. In addition to many Americans being let go, those remaining are expected to work early mornings and/or late evenings to accommodate the Indian developers' work schedule. Frequent layoffs have been a catalyst for the evolution of a toxic work culture. Workers find little inspiration in not knowing from one day to the next if they or their colleagues will be let go. Loyalty to the company is not a desirable characteristic. Younger employees are quitting CDK at what looks to be an accelerating rate. A catastrophic effect of the layoffs is the loss of domain knowledge. Increasingly, no one can learn how things work or how to get things done because those who did know are no longer around. Tasks that used to take hours now can take days, if they even can be done at all. Benefits have suffered, especially health insurance. CDK claims to have benefits competitive with the rest of the industry, but anecdotal evidence belies this. Premiums rise every year, along with deductibles. The office environment is abysmal. Long rows of tables serve as work areas. Employees are spaced six feet apart from right to left and about five feet from those sitting in the next row. This is mitigated somewhat by the number of employees who have chosen to work from home. Some employees feel the need to talk loudly on the phone with no regard for their colleagues. Complaints to management fall on deaf ears. CDK no longer pays for parking. The net result for the CDK's customers is a decline in service and quality.

review_title: A once great company in decline
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than 8 years
pros: The locations in Seattle and Portland are perfect. Customer base is putting up with the products for the time being.
cons: When they moved us from the cubicles into the noisy cafeteria work environment to save money, everything changed. New management appeared from nowhere and were arrogant beyond anything I had ever seen. In the first meeting a vice president smiled as he said things that we all knew were lies as if to see if anyone would challenge him. Everyone left the meeting in silence. In the first layoff, they claimed that they couldn't decide whether or not to lay one employee off, so they made him write an essay to tell them why he's important to the organization -- yes, they made him beg for his job. They laid him off anyway. After that our manager asked us for feedback on how to improve things. The two people who offered suggestions were laid off in the next round. We quickly learned not to make suggestions or complain about anything. The offshoring of development was terrible. You needed to call India regularly to make sure they were doing what you thought they were doing. The time I didn't do this, I found that they were writing code in a different language than what we told them to use. My boss said that offshore code should only require "a tweak or two" before we test it, but everything we got from them was incomplete or defective required a lot of rework. There was no way to prevent it. Management seemed obsessed with the stock price. I heard one manager complaining that the stock price of Broadridge (an earlier ADP spin off) was soaring and he couldn't understand why CDK's wasn't. There were never any long term goals, and our customers were becoming so frustrated with our new products that we were unable to ship any new code for months which turned our agile development into a farce.

pros: - Fairly mature engineering culture, so you may have the opportunity work with very smart people, learn a lot and gain hands on experience with modern technologies - Fantastic location on top of public transit hub
cons: - Compensation is relatively poor and management will not address the issue; for months I had open conversations with my manager and director indicating that I was being compensated at about 80% of market rate and was concerned about that. I gave them a chance to address the concerns and for months I was told that they were working on it, but I left the company feeling like they never would have adequately addressed my concerns - Offshore model is ingrained in the company's DNA, which surfaces in the form of imposing off-hour meetings and on-shore resources serving as first-line support and troubleshooting - Poor work-life balance; not only did the meetings with offshore impose significantly on my personal life, but my manager called me on weekends and evenings on multiple occasions for production support. In order to be promoted, you need to put in the extra hours and I observed that the more senior one became, the more their work-life balance suffered. Pager duty on my team. - Mediocrity is fully accepted; I worked with multiple under-producing teammates at CDK and they were not held accountable, which felt like a toxic culture to me. A Senior Engineer on my team became like an elephant in the room for the entire team (manager included) and yet, I'm sure he's still there collecting paychecks to this day - istently asked to take technical shortcuts due to unrealistic business deadlines; this was true on almost every project at almost every turn - Business often dictates project timelines and technical solutions without regard for engineering input; plus my engineering manager and product owner bickered like a married couple frequently It seemed like almost everyone I worked with was dissatisfied in their position and many of them sought advice on how they themselves could find a way to leave the company; moving to a company where people don't hate their jobs and the company actually cares about employees was a revelation.

Left this company and got a 30% raise to go elsewhere after 15 years of being told "you're average." Right...and the monkey pushes the button. There is no career growth and if you want to work in tech this place pigeon holes you into roles that are difficult to translate to "the real world." I honestly feel like I just got out of an abusive relationship and found out that not all companies treat their people this way, that's how bad this place is. That's a lie. I was there for a year and rarely did any coding. So any new coders looking to make this an entry level development job, please beware of this. The work is tedious, repetitive and definitely NOT what you expect when they advertise it to you Also, for the Content department, they tell you that you will start out as a contractor and after so many months(1-6months), you will become full time and get the benefits. That is a lie. There are people there who have been contractors for over a year and when they question management about it, their response is "I don't know whats going on." By being a contractor you get paid less, you don't have benefits, you don't have sick days or vacation days and they can call you after work to fire you WHENEVER they feel like it without reasoning(I know multiple people who this has happened to). I've seen a contractor who was there for THREE days get fired because the trainer "didn't like them because they asked too many questions" There is no such thing as a warning or write up and if management happens to give you a "warning", more than likely you will be fired once you get home the same day. So there is no job security and also difficult to trust what the two managers say which is ridiculous because they are the managers. There is minimal growth within the company. Upper management schedules meetings with employees to hear concerns and then cancels them because the person claims to be "too busy." That should give you insight about how much they care about the well being of the employees. All that seems to really matter is pleasing the stockholders. Although I was able to get in fulltime before all the madness happened with the contractor business, its sucked to see so many employees get treated unfairly while people in charged laughed behind their backs. People have families they have to provide for and the way this company is handling how they treat contractors shows that they don't really care about the well being of the employee. So that should be a red flag to anyone looking to join this department in CDK. I can't speak on other departments but as far as being a Web Specialist, I honestly would not recommend this place to anyone. This place is a revolving door when it comes to employees so I would stay clear of this company unless you really need the work.

This would cause us to miss out on additional pay during certain months. Also, because of all these issues, it would take upwards of 5-6 months to be paid out on our upsells. main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than a year
pros: Truly enjoyed working with everyone around me. Coworkers are caring, knowledgeable, and eager to help when they can.
cons: The biggest con I can think of is the large disconnect between the VPs/"Senior Leadership"(the boys club), and the rest of the company. Through their "leadership" we have seen 4 rounds of layoffs some of which have been large in the last year. Although my department was never impacted in these layoffs, it still tanked moral and since no one is supposed to talk or ask questions about it (we were told not to ask by our director), everyone basically is wondering when their turn will be. Work life balance is non-existent. I experienced this as a junior engineer, and it only gets worse the more senior you get. To give some background, we are told by senior leadership that they strive to have 50-50 balance between offshore and onshore engineering workforces. However, in my almost two years at the company I was the only onshore member of my 6 man team. Yes, my department had around 20 engineers onshore, but each of those were only a tiny portion of their respective teams. Essentially, they have kept the bare minimum onshore to deal with production issues during the day time. I have no doubt that if the product was more reliable, all onshore members would be let go and replaced by offshore engineers. Back to the work life balance now, as mentioned, the majority of engineers are in India which means the onshore members consistently have to take late night meetings (at the start of the India workday), followed by early morning meetings (at the end of the India workday). When there is a production issue, which happens a good amount, engineers can expect to have 10-12 hour workdays and then still be expected to have the late night and early morning meetings to handoff and pickup the issue with the offshore teams. The company has a lot of confusion about its direction. Engineers are given fiscal year goals and these goals will impact bonuses, raises, and potentially their job status, but the goals are not achievable. There is little planning or communication with product management and engineers/architects before the goals get set either, so unrelistict expectations are set that can't be achieved. The company is trying to move to up-to-date tech stacks, but there is too much politics to play to get any new services set up. From my experience, CDK only rewards hard work by giving more hard work. Yes, you may get your yearly bonus, but don't expect a raise worth much. Pay is below average, but Glassdoor can tell you that. Benefits are pretty standard, I guess. 401k seems good until you realize that you have to wait 3 years in order for any contributions to be vested. As mentioned before, there is currently a culture of fear and low morale. When I was hired I was told that a great company culture was the greatest benefit. It has been quite a change in less than 2 years. I really am not trying to sound bitter, I left liking everyone I worked with, including the offshore engineers, but I can't agree with how the company treats the engineers and every other employee.

review_title: Compensation is Bad, Management is Worse
main_text: I worked at CDK Global full-time for more than a year
pros: Bagels on Mondays and takeout food on Fridays Coworkers are generally cool Scheduling is flexible
cons: The detailed negative reviews and vague, buzzwordy positive ones should be your first clue about this place. There are truly few good things to say about CDK. Most departments are understaffed, overworked, and underpaid, which is reflected in product quality and employee morale. Pay is acceptable only if it's your first job out of college. Raises are insultingly small, and benefits get worse with time. Promotions are handed out based on favoritism; witch hunts and mistreatment based on petty personal vendettas are common. Bad management results in bitter antagonism and resentment between teams who should be working together. There are no healthy outlets for employees to voice their concerns - even the most gentle of criticism is met with hostility, and you will be punished for speaking up. Many US contractors were led to believe they would be hired full-time after a few months, only to have their contracts extended multiple times without their knowledge or consent. Meanwhile, a team was hired in India to "help with their workload." Numbers are worshipped at the expense of employees and customers. Upper management does not see employees as assets, but as items on a balance sheet. Zero opportunities for growth or advancement, few opportunities to learn transferable skills. They are quickly trying to outsource the bulk of the work and turn the remaining US offices into call centers. Many employees now spend most of their time cleaning up after the messes created by CDK's outsourced, poorly trained, cheap labor, and customers are increasingly unhappy. WFH is advertised but is mostly for the unlucky souls working every Saturday. Otherwise, it's not available until you've been FT for almost a year - and then you only get two days a month.* Exceptions are not made for inclement weather or unsafe office conditions. Meanwhile, managers WFH at their leisure and often with no notice. *When approved, and it can't be the day after/before a holiday or vacation day. They lie about everything. Even things that don't matter. The vast majority of employees are trying to get out as quickly as they can. The only worthwhile thing you'll get from CDK is work experience, if you need it.

review_title: There might be worse companies to work for but all of them pay minimum wage
main_text: I have been working at CDK Global full-time for more than 8 years
pros: I seldom have to meet management in person. I get a paycheck every two weeks. My coworkers and clients are good people.
cons: Repressive and fear based management. It's all about the bad things management can do to you. Excessive policies and micromanagement make everything take longer. The sticks outweigh the carrots by a large margin. Under staffing and unreasonable workloads make the sticks unavoidable and the carrots, if they exist at all, unattainable. Management is easy to talk to but there will be no positive movement, only lip service. Upper management shows no cohesive plan to get us out of the mess they've put us in other than taking it out on the employees. HR is a joke, they’ll rubber stamp anything that gets through legal review. Benefits have become significantly more expensive and more complicated to work through. There is one company car policy for us with two choices, take it or go find another job. They take $100.00 a month out of our check for personal mileage, soon to be raised to $135.00. We also pay taxes on that money. There are two reasons why most of us drive as few personal miles as possible. 1) Extreme Big Brother tracking. A gps and cellular equipped device is plugged into the OBD2 connector. The OBD2 connector knows everything that’s going on with the car right down to whether the doors are locked, brake and throttle position, turn signals, etc. This data along with location, speed, g-force and more is transmitted to a server and stored. They have reserved to right to do anything they want with the data which includes selling our driving record and location data to anyone they want as many times as they want. 2) An 18 page company car policy that forbids many every day, perfectly legal activities. You can’t even pick up a gallon of gas or lighter fluid because all flammables are forbidden. There are multiple scenarios where they reserve the right to charge you the full repair cost and a catch all for anything they missed, whatever THEY determine to be negligence. They've created a way to dishonestly and unethically profit by taking money from their employees that doesn’t belong to them. THEFT. I'd want to know where my people are too but I'd do it in a much different way. It’s just a job and I do it for a paycheck. Moral is at an all-time low everywhere. I’ll take less to work for a company that treats its people with dignity and respect and I’ll work a lot harder for them.
